quotes.text: To figure out your product market fit and how to distribute it, it's not something that you can outsource to somebody.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against assuming a dedicated growth team can “solve” PMF/distribution for the rest of the org.

quotes.text: Never ever once have I seen a rebrand or redesign, especially of UK marketing site produce good performance results.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A strong counterexample to the common belief that brand/website refreshes reliably improve acquisition metrics.

quotes.text: Number three, if every single one of your initiatives that you're doing on growth is an experiment that's a problem. It's almost like a disease, like a paralyzing disease.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable critique of “experiment-only” growth roadmaps that can stall progress instead of driving it.

quotes.text: And my north star metric is insights per minute.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A simple, portable metric for making meetings and communication more outcome-focused and high-signal.

quotes.text: people are grasping for oftentimes things that are completely out of context or they are very specific to one example and actually do not apply as a pattern or simply not even applicable to their type of business whatsoever.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical caution to validate whether a “growth hack” generalizes before applying it to your product and market.

quotes.text: We live in tech, there's always lots of startups. Startups are obviously looking to grow and there is a huge misconception in the shield that in order to get growth going, you need a growth team, absolutely not true.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that hiring a growth team is the prerequisite to starting growth.

quotes.text: In order to get the growth going in the company, a founder and the founding team have to figure out how to make it grow to the first, let's say a million, 5 million, 10 million in ARR.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets a concrete milestone-based expectation that early growth is a founder responsibility up to meaningful revenue scale.

quotes.text: Some of the companies don't even create growth teams until they're a hundred, 200 million in ARR because to figure out your product market fit and how to distribute it's not something that you can outsource to somebody.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides a striking data point and reinforces the mental model that PMF and distribution learning can’t be delegated early.

quotes.text: I really believe that the founder led growth is not being popularized enough that you do not need growth teams until you actually can start running experiments on your user base, which means that you have volume of users that you can learn from and optimize and innovate on, and that first wave of growth has to be founder led.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines a practical gating criterion for hiring growth: enough user volume to run experiments and learn.

quotes.text: And honestly, the longer you wait, the better it is because that way your entire company will be trained to be responsible for growth as opposed to putting this one island with a growth team and saying, "They're going to be growing," and what is the rest of the company doing? Honestly, the longer you wait, the better.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Argues for delaying growth hires to build a company-wide growth ownership culture rather than isolating it in one team.

quotes.topic_title: Growth vs sales: when to hire which
quotes.text: It depends on how you're actually going to collect the monies. If your money collection is going to happen through sales team primarily, then you absolutely should be hiring sales way before growth.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A simple decision rule: hire based on the primary monetization/collection mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Growth vs sales: when to hire which
quotes.text: In fact, in the sales led companies, growth teams are not necessarily needed even that much.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Challenges the default assumption that every B2B SaaS needs a growth team early.

quotes.topic_title: Growth vs sales: when to hire which
quotes.text: You might have a growth marketing team, which is really a demand gen team that is rebranded for growth marketing so they can charge you 20 to 30% more in their salaries, but at the end of the day, sales is doing your monetization.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A pointed warning about mislabeling demand gen as “growth” and overpaying for the wrong function.

quotes.topic_title: Growth vs sales: when to hire which
quotes.text: If you're starting with self-serve monetization, growth hire should be frankly first before sales.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clear hiring order guidance for self-serve/product-led monetization models.

quotes.topic_title: Growth vs sales: when to hire which
quotes.text: If you have any product-led components where product is responsible for acquisition, activation, monetization or retention, that's where growth comes in.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical checklist for when growth becomes necessary based on which levers the product owns.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: That just does not happen. If you have the overall business slowing down, your head of growth is destined to fail because the reason business is slowing down is much deeper than not having a growth team.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Challenges the common reflex to hire growth leadership as a fix for declining performance, pointing to deeper root-cause issues.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: Growth team can optimize, growth can maybe lift it by 10, 15%. Maybe that's enough for you. Even that is on the upper end of what growth team will be able to do if there is a slow-down trajectory.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations for what growth teams can deliver during a slowdown, offering a concrete range practitioners can plan around.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: But what's important is that if you have core product and core marketing issues, growth team will not be able to fix them for you.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clarifies the boundary of responsibility: growth can’t compensate for fundamental product/marketing problems.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: But if you are slowing down and you have issues with either your go-to-market strategy or your core product strategy with your core product market fit, growth is going to be absolutely helpless to do anything.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides a diagnostic rule: if slowdown is driven by GTM or PMF degradation, growth efforts won’t move the needle.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: If you are declining in your revenue growth or whatever other metric that you're looking at, your weekly active users or whatnot, see at least that you're able to plateau it so you can stop the decline.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Gives a practical prerequisite for hiring growth: first stabilize the core metrics before expecting growth to scale them.

quotes.text: But to ever promise a homepage redesign or marketing site redesign in order to drive more acquisition is a failed promise that is going to be led by lots of agency money spending, often a million dollars plus, lots of arguing about which shade of blue your brand color is going to be, and eight to 10 months at the minimum of development and very lackluster results afterwards.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that redesigns are often sold as growth levers but typically burn time and budget with weak outcomes.

quotes.text: Every single time I've seen a marketing site at least rebrand, it's been a step back in performance that then is being treated as a fire drill to fix. Just don't do it if you expect immediate results out of it, or at least educate the team on how long it's going to take to get to the point where you think that there's going to be upside away from your original brand.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets an expectation-management model: assume an initial performance drop and plan the recovery period explicitly.

quotes.text: It's a new starting point and that starting point is going to be much lower than your current optimized experience that you have.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A mental model for redesigns: you reset optimization progress and should expect to rebuild performance from a lower baseline.

quotes.text: The best I've ever seen is that it produced net neutral results and it produced us better ability to optimize towards something bigger. That's the best case scenario.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes “success” for rebrands as enabling future optimization rather than immediate growth.

quotes.text: The goal here should be, we will launch, we will probably see a hit, model out and forecast for a hit, and then give yourself two to three months at the minimum, ideally more like six months, to really optimize it back to a good standing where it can potentially outperform.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides an actionable rollout methodology: forecast the dip and budget 3–6 months post-launch for optimization work.

quotes.text: So knowing what your competition is doing is extremely important. Being inspired by some aspects of what your competition is doing in their experience is a wonderful place to originate an ideation or potentially try to implement into your product as well. But blatantly saying, "Hey, we're going to copy all of these best tactics or all of these flows because, hey, they're doing better than us. Let's just rip them and do exactly the same. Why isn't our onboarding looks the same as this onboarding? This company is so successful."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Draws a clear line between competitive research as an ideation input versus copying competitors as a strategy.

quotes.text: And there's a lot of drive, especially to have it as a shortcut. "Okay, we don't want to go through this ideation or user research. We don't want to do user interviews, but we don't want to do A/B testing. It works for them. It must work for us. Let's just go and do it." And it fails 95% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Warns that skipping discovery and experimentation by copying “proven” competitor tactics is a high-probability failure mode.

quotes.text: I also think that there is a lot of patterns you start to notice as you start tearing down all of these companies. You're like, "Oh, these elements are always the same." That means all of these companies are arriving to these things and they seem to be winning elements. And you can take those elements and put them into your product, but you can never skip the ideation, the design, the user research, the customer interview, the experimentation step.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology: extract recurring “winning elements” across products, but still run the full product development loop.

quotes.text: And you should always balance it with actually innovating yourself in your product. Because copying competition is like the fastest way to mediocrity because you'll never be a leader if you copied somebody else.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes copying as an anti-leadership strategy and argues for differentiation alongside pattern adoption.

quotes.text: Benchmarks are also very dangerous here to use because benchmarks are usually done on all of the competition, on all of the softwares out there. And the way people define numbers is so different from company to company.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Challenges the common reliance on benchmarks by highlighting inconsistent metric definitions that make comparisons misleading.

quotes.text: I'm very sorry to break it to all of you, but your problem is not unique. I am 99% sure of that.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A blunt mental-model reset that pushes teams to stop assuming their growth challenges are unprecedented and start learning from existing solutions.

quotes.text: And number one thing that whenever you have an initiative or whenever you have a metric that you need to go and move, to not start from scratch, ever. Do not start from scratch. It's the worst thing that you can do because you can waste so many cycles on trying to do something that probably has already been solved
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to default to reuse (research, precedents, patterns) rather than reinventing, to reduce time-to-solution and opportunity cost.

quotes.text: You should go find people that have solved this problem because there are people there and people love to talk about what they do. So take advantage of that human psychology and go find those people and just ask them, "How did you do it? What did you do? What happened?"
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical methodology: use direct outreach as a shortcut to proven playbooks instead of relying only on internal trial-and-error.

quotes.text: Make patterns. Make patterns out of your solutions.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable directive to turn one-off fixes into reusable frameworks so teams can move faster across future problems.

quotes.text: the question is, how much time do you have to fail?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing of growth experimentation: failure is expected, but the limiting factor is the number of failure cycles your company/market can afford.

quotes.text: Yes, so we just launched OneSchema file feeds, which allows you to build an integration with any system in 15 minutes as long as you can export a CSV to an SFTP folder.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A concrete, time-bound methodology for rapidly shipping CSV-based integrations via a simple prerequisite (CSV to SFTP).

quotes.text: We see our customers all the time getting stuck with hacks and workarounds and the product teams that we work with don't have to turn down prospects because their systems are too hard to integrate with.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: Highlights a practical go-to-market lever: removing integration friction can directly prevent lost deals.

quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of multi-day outages from even just a handful of ad records.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A vivid reliability lesson that small data issues can cascade into major operational outages.

quotes.text: We have a built-in validation layer that stops any bad data from entering your system, and OneSchema will notify your team immediately of any data that looks incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: An actionable integration reliability pattern: validate at the boundary and alert immediately on anomalies.

quotes.text: So the first is, wait longer than you think to hire a head of growth. Wait until you have product market fit, maybe a million, or especially if you're self-serve oriented.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring guidance that ties growth leadership timing to PMF and revenue/self-serve readiness.

quotes.text: So the first is, wait longer than you think to hire a head of growth. Wait until you have product market fit, maybe a million, or especially if you're self-serve oriented.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable hiring guidance that reframes growth leadership as a post-PMF lever, especially for self-serve products.

quotes.text: Number two is if your growth is declining, the head of growth won't solve that problem. First, stop the decline at least.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that hiring growth leaders won’t fix a shrinking core—stabilization must come first.

quotes.text: Third is redesigning your homepage, marketing page. Rebranding is not only not going to help you grow, it's going to probably hurt growth and slow things down. And so just go into that wide eyes wide open.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Practical caution against relying on redesigns/rebrands as growth strategies, highlighting likely negative impact and opportunity cost.

quotes.text: These things are a lot more patternized than you would expect them to be, so go and find those patterns as opposed to trying to re-engineer it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A reusable growth methodology: treat activation/monetization issues as known patterns to discover and apply rather than reinvent.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #6: Growth teams over-focus on paid/SEO
quotes.text: However, as a growth team, your number one priority is to create your own or your earned channel. So channel that you've earned and that nobody else can compete in but you.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A clear prioritization framework: growth teams should focus first on building owned/earned acquisition channels that are defensible.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #6: Growth teams over-focus on paid/SEO
quotes.text: An algorithm can giveth, but algorithm can also taketh away at any point. And you have no control because you don't own those channels.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable risk model for SEO/paid/social: algorithm-dependent channels are inherently unstable and outside your control.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #6: Growth teams over-focus on paid/SEO
quotes.text: Referrals from people to people are everything.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A strong, actionable emphasis on referral loops as a primary acquisition lever in product-led growth.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #6: Growth teams over-focus on paid/SEO
quotes.text: Focusing on these earned channels that you own becomes the outmost priority. And if you don't have them on your growth roadmap, you are going to be in some really big trouble over the next year to two years because your cost of acquisition is only going to go up.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete planning directive and time-bound warning: earned channels should be explicitly on the roadmap to avoid rising CAC.

quotes.topic_title: Mistake #6: Growth teams over-focus on paid/SEO
quotes.text: It's not cheapest. It's actually cost a lot of product and engineering and even marketing resources to stand up. So it's not the cost of a budget, but it's cost of people that will have to work to create your own channel, so to speak, for acquisition.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive clarification that “earned” channels aren’t free—they require meaningful cross-functional investment.
